    • Turn a programming project into a corpus

Turn a programming project into a corpus

vignette_construct_corpus.Rmd

codexplor::construct_corpus read programming files and turn a programming project into a text-mining corpus, given :

  • folder(s) path(s) and/or github repo(s) to analyze ;
  • and programming language(s) - default is 'R'.

Supported languages. By default construct_corpus will analyze .R files, but one or several languages could be indicated. Recognized languages are R, Python, JavaScript.

Examples 

library(codexplor)

# 1) Construct a corpus without a Citations network
  corp <- construct_corpus( repos =  "clement-LVD/codexplor", languages = "R")
#> 
#> Content is fixed by adding 2 closing separator(s) !
  
  str(corp, max.level = 1) 
#> List of 3
#>  $ codes   :Classes 'corpus.lines' and 'data.frame': 1463 obs. of  11 variables:
#>  $ comments:Classes 'corpus.lines' and 'data.frame': 935 obs. of  9 variables:
#>  $ nodelist:Classes 'corpus.nodelist' and 'data.frame':  24 obs. of  7 variables:
#>  - attr(*, "class")= chr [1:2] "list" "corpus.list"
#>  - attr(*, "date_creation")= Date[1:1], format: "2025-03-05"
#>  - attr(*, "have_citations_network")= logi FALSE
#>  - attr(*, "languages_patterns")=List of 1
#>  - attr(*, "repos")= chr "clement-LVD/codexplor"
 # Example : several local folders and repos
corpus <- construct_corpus(c("~", "M:/") languages = "R"
, repos =  c("clement-LVD/codexplor","tidyverse/stringr"))

# Example : several languages
corpus_py <- construct_corpus(repos = "secdev/scapy"
, languages = c("Python", "Javascript"), .verbose = T) #take a while

Returned list of dataframes

construct_corpus return a corpus.list object, a standard list of 3 dataframes :

  • codes (classes corpus.lines & data.frame)
  • comments (classes corpus.lines & data.frame)
  • nodelist (classes corpus.nodelist & data.frame)

Complementary analyzes will add others dataframes to the list, e.g., a network of internal dependencies (classes citations.network, internal.dependencies & data.frame).

  • The nodelist data.frame is sorted by files, and contains the files path and/or url, and overall text-mining metrics about each files of the corpus (e.g., number of characters, words count).

  • The 2 corpus.lines data.frame are related to lines (file path and content of each lines, line number, and text-mining metrics related to each lines).

The codes data.frame (one of the corpus.lines dataframes) have more columns, such as :

  • a commented column (inline comment at the end of a codeline)
  • and a matches column that contain internally-exposed functions names, e.g., if a pol <- function is defined within a file, the 1st matches corresponding entry for this line will be 'pol'.

Default patterns

construct_corpus rely on some default patterns, designed to analyze a programming project in a standardized way. With these patterns, construct_corpus will :

  1. read the files accordingly to their extension, e.g., R language is associated with '.R' files.
  2. process commented lines accordingly to each language definition, e.g., R & Python use '#' and don’t allow multi-lines comments, contrary to JavaScript.
  3. isolate the exposed content, i.e. not within a '{ }'.
  4. match functions names within the exposed content.

The hereafter table show some examples of a hello function defined in several languages : construct_corpus have to match 'hello', despite of the differences between languages.

Example Definition Keyword Operator After Keyword Operator After Name Start Instructions operator anonymous
JavaScript function hello() { } function ( { FALSE
Python def hello(): pass def ( : FALSE
R hello <- function() { } function ( <-|= { TRUE

Here, R is the only language that assign an anonymous function to an object. Thus, contrary to other languages, we have to find the name of R functions before the keyword ‘function’, R parameters names are within the parenthesis after ‘function(’, etc.

Unmatched func’ def’

The function ‘hello’ defined as a lambda (anonymous) function within the Python line hereafter is not matched by construct_corpus :

 hello = lambda: None

Another caveat unsupported - yet - is the ‘hello’ javascript function defined hereafter :

 const hello = (a, b) => a + b;

About duplicated lines associated with 1st matches

During the 1st matches extraction, lines are duplicated when several matches are found on the same line. This case of duplicated lines trigger a warning.

For example, by default, the names of functions defined in the files of the project are extracted during the 1st match operated by construct_corpus. If a file have several function defined within the same line, such a line will be duplicated in the returned df, with several ‘matches’ along these lines and same line_number.

Helper functions that rely on construct_corpus

codexplor::get_doc_network_from_project is an helper ‘high-level’ function that perform an analysis of the internal dependencies by performing a 2nd matches from the 1st matches of construct_corpus, e.g., see the vignette about analyzing a network of internal dependencies with get_doc_network_from_project.
